greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = x(n+1)/x(n) - 1 where x(1)=1 and x(k) = x(k-1) + lcm(x(k-1),k).
comment: This sequence has properties related to primes. For instance: terms consist of 1's or primes only; if 3 never occurs, any prime p occurs finitely many times.
All prime numbers 'p' from the sequence A014963(n), which equals A003418(n+1)/A003418(n), are in a(n-1) = p. - _Eric Desbiaux_, Jan 11 2015

For any prime p > 3, a(p-1) = p. Also a(n) is not 3 for any n. All terms but a(1) and a(3) are odd, and probably all of them are not composite numbers; this is strongly related to a strong version of Linnik's Theorem (see Ruiz-Cabello link). - _Serafín Ruiz-Cabello_, Sep 30 2015
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Serafín Ruiz-Cabello, On the use of the lowest common multiple to build a prime-generating recurrence, arXiv:1504.05041 [math.CO], 2015.
mathematica: a[n_] := x[n+1]/x[n] - 1; x[1] = 1; x[k_] := x[k] = x[k-1] + LCM[x[k-1], k]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 88}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 08 2013 *)
results.author: _Benoit Cloitre_, Feb 09 2008
